docs.snippet: LEAD:    A Bit of Texas Downtown Looking more like a truck stop than a cafe, the new Texas Tortilla Bakery, 36 Water Street (near Coenties Slip) in Manhattan easily satisfies a hunger for warm, fresh tortillas, mellow beans, lightly charred chicke...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: A Bit of Texas Downtown Looking more like a truck stop than a cafe, the new Texas Tortilla Bakery, 36 Water Street (near Coenties Slip) in Manhattan easily satisfies a hunger for warm, fresh tortillas, mellow beans, lightly charred chicken or beef fajitas and salsa with a gentle kick. The bakery and cafe is open for dining in or taking out.

docs.snippet: On an inconspicuous street in lower Manhattan sits R. J. Max Fine Foods, a recently opened takeout, delivery and catering business that is owned by Roman Dashevsky and Roman Lozovsky, who are brothers-in-law. Situated at 55 Ann Street (between Nas...
docs.abstract: R J Max Fine Foods, takeout and delivery food business, is opened by Roman Dashevsky and Roman Lozovsky at 44 Ann Street in lower Manhattan (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: On an inconspicuous street in lower Manhattan sits R. J. Max Fine Foods, a recently opened takeout, delivery and catering business that is owned by Roman Dashevsky and Roman Lozovsky, who are brothers-in-law. Situated at 55 Ann Street (between Nassau and William Streets), the two men offer breakfast, lunch and dinner to the weekday Wall Street crowd and cater parties and corporate events. Mr. Dashevsky, the chef, is trained in Russian and French cooking. He has owned La Petite Maison Russe in Woodmere, N.Y., as well as a catering company on the Upper East Side with Mr. Lozovsky. The menu, a fusion of international styles, includes harcho, a spicy Georgian soup prepared with lamb and served with country bread ($3.75); a daily roast special, either pork, veal or baby chicken, served with a vegetable, potato or rice ($6.50 to $9), or salmon coulibiac, with the fish served in a mushroom-and-dill sauce and wrapped in a pastry ($9). Tarts, pies and cakes ($2 to $3.50) are all made daily on the premises.

headline.main: Takeout Shop With a Russian Accent

docs.snippet: THE Hamptons have long been blessed with some wonderful sources for high-quality foods. Simple fishermen's markets sell seafood from nearby waters, farm stands overflow with produce in season and charming little catering shops fill orders for sala...
docs.abstract: The Hamptons are blessed with diverse and plentiful food markets; listing; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE Hamptons have long been blessed with some wonderful sources for high-quality foods. Simple fishermen's markets sell seafood from nearby waters, farm stands overflow with produce in season and charming little catering shops fill orders for salads and cocktail party fare. But the food shopping scene is changing. In recent years, the markets have been expanding, becoming more diverse in response to a demanding clientele that wants not only more variety, but also the convenience of one-stop food shopping. For example, the Green Thumb in Water Mill now carries breads and cheeses as well as produce.

headline.main: When It Comes to Take-Out, Markets Expand to Fill Need
